data.title: what's on, tickets and everything you need to know
data.meta_description: The festival is back and bigger than ever - here's what you can expect
data.text:
Homotopia 2017 in Liverpool - what's on, tickets and everything you need to know

The festival is back and bigger than ever - here's what you can expect

Liverpool ’s Homotopia festival returns to the city this week for a 14th year of dance, drama, art, music, talks, readings and debate.

The radical series of events starts on Thursday, October 26 to celebrate everything about lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender art and culture.

‌

The festival - which will run all through November and end on December 1 - boasts more than 50 events and there will be more than 1,000 LGBT+ artists performing.

So to help you learn more about the fantastic festival, we have put together an ultimate guide about everything you need to know about it.

What is Homotopia?

Homotopia is a Liverpool-based arts and social justice organisation that unites and inspires communities.

‌

Liverpool Echo Icon

Sign up to FREE email alerts from ECHO Daily News

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you’ve consented to and improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and third parties based on our knowledge of you. More info

It brings audiences and artists to Liverpool, and every November Homotopia puts on an annual festival of local, national and international LGBT+ arts and culture.

READ MORE: UK's largest gin festival coming to Liverpool this winter

It has utilised the city’s arts spaces, and this year the festival presents #Liberation50, which relates to how the past 50 years has affected and shaped LGBTQI culture.

‌

Homotopia will focus on forgotten stories and it looks at what the anniversary means for LGBTQI artists, and what the last 50 years has meant for the community.

Where is it taking place?

Events are being held at various locations across the city, including the Walker Art Gallery, Unity Theatre, The Bluecoat and FACT.

‌

What are the highlights?

Some of the performances include:

Coming Out: Sexuality, Gender and Identity

‌

Coming Out: Sexuality, Gender and Identity brings together a variety of artists who have used their work to explore sexuality and gender identity since 1967.

FREE

On now until November 5, 10am to 5pm.

‌

Walker Art Gallery, William Brown Street, L3 8EL.

READ MORE: What's on in Liverpool's theatres in the run up to Christmas 2017

‌

Brian Epstein: Remembering The Beatles’ manager

The Beatles Story has launched a new exhibition to honour the life and achievements of Brian Epstein.

‌

Tickets are from £12.

On now until November

The Beatles Story, Albert Dock, L3 4AD.

‌

READ MORE: Crazy Pedro's famous pizza parlour reveal opening date - here's what to expect

‌

Fashion Icons: Celebrating Gay Designers

This small display of 14 outfits celebrates the work of some of the best-known fashion designers – all of whom were or are gay.

They include Christian Dior, John Galliano, Yves Saint Laurent, Dolce and Gabbana and Karl Lagerfeld.

‌

FREE.

On now until October 29, 10am to 5pm.

Walker Art Gallery , William Brown Street, L3 8EL.

‌

READ MORE: Bangkok Lady Boys are coming to Merseyside next month

‌

Designing Desire

This is a pop-up exhibition by three artists.

It looks at the visual arts, technological production, scientific exploration and political activism to consider the future of 3D printing.

‌

FREE.

On now until November 5

FACT, 88 Wood Street, L1 4DQ.

‌

READ MORE: Confessions of a Scouse naked butler - what Butlers in the Buff is really like

‌

Martin Huiskens: Collages

‌

This will touch on themes such as the HIV/AIDs crisis to violence against women, masculinity and racism.

FREE

Opens October 26 to November 25.

‌

Unity Theatre, first floor bar, 1 Hope Pl, L1 9BG.

READ MORE: Liverpool Santa Dash 2017 runners can enjoy special After Bash with mulled wine and hog roast

Creative Rage

‌

Creative Rage is group show of artists who explore anger, bravery and non-conformity.

On Friday, October 27 at 2pm there will be a tour of the exhibition and a Q&A with some of the artists.

From October 27 to November 12.

‌

FREE

The Gallery, 41 Stanhope St, L8 5RE.

‌

Rent Party

Rent Party is a brand new musical about being poor, black and gay.

‌

Tuesday, October 31.

£5

Unity Theatre

‌

‌

READ MORE: Yard and Coop in Liverpool ONE is giving away free fried chicken and chips

‌

Son of Liverpool

This is a theatre-verse exploration of birth, life, death.

Thursday, November 2, 7.30pm.

‌

Tickets cost £6 (£5 for concessions)

Unity Theatre

‌

‘Dear Edna’

David Hoyle presents a tribute to the work and legacy of Joe Orton.

‌

Saturday November 4, 4pm.

FREE - Pre-booking is essential.

Tate Liverpool, Albert Dock , Liverpool, L3 4BB.

‌

READ MORE: Lobster Pot are now serving deep-fried battered Mars bars

‌

“Do You Mind If I Smoke…?” Memoirs of Fenella Fielding

Fielding is renowned for her appearances in classic film comedies such as, ‘Carry On Screaming’, ‘Doctor in Clover’ and ‘Carry On Regardless’.

Saturday, November 4, 7.30pm.

‌

£12 (£10 cost concessions).

Unity Theatre.

‌

‌

You’ve Changed

Challenging the idea that genitals equal gender, Kate bares all, and explores what’s down there and what’s up here.

£10 (£8 for concessions)

‌

Tuesday, November 7, 7.30pm.

Unity Theatre.

‌

Schools Out and LGBT History Month 2018 Launch

This aims to celebrate LGBT history, which has become invisible by the legal and educational systems.

‌

FREE

Wednesday, November 8, 6pm.

Museum of Liverpool, Pier Head, Liverpool, L3 1DG.

‌

READ MORE: Life inside Sugar & Dice - Liverpool's first board game cafe

‌

Maggi Hambling, In Conversation

Hambling has established a reputation over five decades as one of the country’s most significant painters and sculptors.

The artist talks about her work, her “lesbionic” life and her inspirations.

‌

£5 - and booking is essential.

Wednesda,y November 8, 6pm.

Tate Liverpool, Albert Dock, Liverpool Waterfront, Liverpool, L3 4BB.

‌

Out

‌

Challenging homophobia and transphobia within Caribbean communities, OUT is the conversation between two bodies.

Wednesday, November 8, 7.30pm.

£8 (£6 for concessions)

‌

Unity Theatre.

READ MORE: Confessions of a Scouse naked butler - what Butlers in the Buff is really like

‌

ĐẸP

Đẹp means beautiful in Vietnamese.

‌

A Vietnamese-born gay artist Van Huynh draws us into a very personal and intimate world in the UK.

Thursday November 9, 7.30pm.

Tickets cost £10 (£8 for concessions).

‌

Recommended for 16 years of age and over.

Unity Theatre.

‌

‌

EAT ME and Preach!

This showcases the shiniest drag artists.

‌

Friday November 10, 7.30pm.

£5 - £20

The Invisible Wind Factory, 3 Regent Road, L7 3DS.

‌

READ MORE: Liverpool craft brewery teams up with BrewDog to brew a limited edition beer

‌

David Hoyle: Diamond

Diamond is a queer performance of sexuality and British culture that looks at LGBT times from 1957 to 2017.

Diamond charts David’s rise from a gay teen, through popular TV anti-drag queen cult phenomena Divine David.

‌

It then looks at the performer he is today.

There will be special guests the LipSinkers.

Saturday, November 11, 7.30pm.

‌

£12 to £10 (£10 - £8 for concessions).

The Unity Theatre.

‌

‌

The Butch Monologues

A powerful and humorous collection of secret stories that explore sexuality, vulnerability and desire.

Saturday, November 11, 9.30pm.

‌

£10 (£8 for concessions).

Unity Theatre.

‌

‌

Emily Pope screening and artist discussion

Pope will screen the most recent episode of her sitcom.

She will also discuss the six-part video series which reflects on film’s ability to perform a reflexive diary.

‌

It will analyse personal and collective relationships to humour, capital and society.

FREE.

Wednesday, November 15, 6.30pm.

‌

Royal Standard, Northern Lights, Cains Brewery Village, Grafton St, L8 5SD.

‌

The Killing of Sister George

The 1967 Sexual Offenses Act was a reference to male sex, but this will look at, ‘Where are the lesbians?’.

Thursday, November 16.

‌

£10.

Picturehouse at FACT, 88 Wood St, Liverpool, L1 4DQ.

READ MORE: These Morrisons coats are almost identical to designer versions - but £3k cheaper

‌

Mapping Memories: Whatever Happened to the Hollywood TNT?

‌

An informal get together with original writers, theatre-makers, artists, cast and collaborators from the city’s electrically-charged queer underground of the late 1980’s and early 1990s.

FREE - but booking is essential.

Saturday, November 18, 2pm.

‌

The Bluecoat.

‌

The Leather Boys

This classic British sixties movie follows the lives of two young newly weds, Dot and Reggie, their marriage ends up scuppered.

When Reggie moves in with his mate Pete he finds a new world.

‌

FREE - but booking is essential.

Tuesday, November 21, 6pm.

Red Brick Vintage, The Courtyard, Cains Brewery Village, Stanhope Street, Liverpool L8 5XJ.

‌

READ MORE: Tickets for Coyote Ugly Liverpool opening night on sale TODAY

‌

David Bowie Made Me Gay

Darryl’s latest book, ‘David Bowie Made Me Gay’ looks at the lives of the people who made these records.

He focuses on how LGBT+ performers encouraged Jazz and Blues.

‌

He examines the nearly forgotten Pansy Craze in the years between the two World Wars.

£2 or £3.

Wednesday, November 22, 6.30pm.

‌

Waterstones, 12 College Lane, L1 3DL.

‌

Queercentric – Music Night

This will have UK Queer Music Scene's beats, rhythms and lyrical qualities.

£5 and £3 for students (pay cash on the door).

‌

Wednesday, November 22, 7pm.

At HUS, 12 Tithebarn Street, L2 2DT.

READ MORE: Harry Potter exhibition opens in Liverpool Central Library

‌

The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin

‌

His novels have encouraged many to declare their own truth and this follows his evolution from a conservative son of the Old South into a gay rights pioneer.

£10.

November 23, 6.30pm.

‌

Picturehouse at FACT, 88 Wood Street, L1 4DQ.

‌

1967: Where are all the lesbians?

This will explore whether life was easier for lesbians and bi woman in the 1960s than for gay men.

FREE - but booking is essential.

‌

Saturday, November 25, 4pm.

A secret location.

‌

Closing event with Travis Alabanza

The last event of this year’s Homotopia, will see Notes on Queerness and an evening of live art led by performance artist Travis Alabanza.

‌

With a special guest appearance from festival favourite David Hoyle.

FREE - but booking is essential.

Saturday, November 25.

‌

The Royal Standard, Cains Brewery Village, Grafton St, L8 5SD.

‌

How to get tickets

A lot of the events are FREE to attend.

But some charge.
